messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Polynomial-Time Pseudodeterministic Construction of Primes

Paper Abstract: Abstract A randomized algorithm for a search problem is pseudodeterministic if it produces a fixed canonical solution to the search problem with high probability. In their seminal work on the topic, Gat and Goldwasser [GG11] posed as their main open problem whether prime numbers can be pseudodeterministically constructed in polynomial time. We provide a positive solution to this question in the infinitely-often regime. In more detail, we give an unconditional polynomial-time randomized algorithm BùêµB such that, for infinitely many values of nùëõn, B‚Äã(1n)ùêµsuperscript1ùëõB(1^{n}) outputs a canonical nùëõn-bit prime pnsubscriptùëùùëõp_{n} with high probability. More generally, we prove that for every dense property QùëÑQ of strings that can be decided in polynomial time, there is an infinitely-often pseudodeterministic polynomial-time construction of strings satisfying QùëÑQ. This improves upon a subexponential-time construction of Oliveira and Santhanam [OS17]. Our construction uses several new ideas, including a novel bootstrapping technique for pseudodeterministic constructions, and a quantitative optimization of the uniform hardness-randomness framework of Chen and Tell [CT21], using a variant of the Shaltiel‚ÄìUmans generator [SU05].

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Computational Complexity: A Modern Approach",
        "PRIMES is in ¬∂¬∂\\P",
        "Zero-knowledge protocols for search problems",
        "The difference between consecutive primes. II",
        "Lower bounds for pseudo-deterministic counting in a stream",
        "How to generate cryptographically strong sequences of pseudo-random bits",
        "Query complexity of search problems",
        "A map of witness maps: New definitions and connections",
        "On the order of magnitude of the difference between consecutive prime numbers",
        "Unstructured hardness to average-case randomness",
        "Hardness vs randomness, revised: Uniform, non-black-box, and instance-wise",
        "On pseudodeterministic approximation algorithms",
        "Complete problems for multi-pseudodeterministic computations",
        "Pseudodeterminism: promises and lowerbounds",
        "Probabilistic search algorithms with unique answers and their cryptographic applications",
        "Bipartite perfect matching in pseudo-deterministic \\NC\\NC\\NC",
        "Matroid intersection: A pseudo-deterministic parallel reduction from search to weighted-decision",
        "Pseudo-deterministic proofs",
        "Doubly-efficient pseudo-deterministic proofs",
        "Pseudo-deterministic streaming",
        "On the possibilities and limitations of pseudodeterministic algorithms",
        "On the pseudo-deterministic query complexity of \\NP\\NP\\NP search problems",
        "Delegating computation: interactive proofs for muggles",
        "A hard-core predicate for all one-way functions",
        "Reproducibility and pseudo-determinism in Log-Space",
        "Computational complexity: a conceptual perspective",
        "On the doubly-efficient interactive proof systems of GKR",
        "On doubly-efficient interactive proof systems",
        "Multi-pseudodeterministic algorithms",
        "Finding primitive roots pseudo-deterministically",
        "Highly resilient correctors for polynomials",
        "Uniform constant-depth threshold circuits for division and iterated multiplication",
        "Constant-depth circuits for arithmetic in finite fields of characteristic two",
        "In search of an easy witness: exponential time vs. probabilistic polynomial time",
        "¬∂=\\BPP¬∂\\BPP\\P=\\BPP if \\E\\E\\E requires exponential circuits: Derandomizing the XOR lemma",
        "Randomness vs time: Derandomization under a uniform assumption",
        "Circuit-size lower bounds and non-reducibility to sparse sets",
        "Some connections between nonuniform and uniform complexity classes",
        "Computing œÄ‚Äã(x)ùúãùë•\\pi(x): An analytic method",
        "Theory and applications of probabilistic Kolmogorov complexity",
        "Pseudodeterministic algorithms and the structure of probabilistic time",
        "3.1‚Äãn‚àío‚Äã(n)3.1ùëõùëúùëõ3.1n-o(n) circuit lower bounds for explicit functions",
        "Super-polynomial versus half-exponential circuit size in the exponential hierarchy",
        "Hardness vs randomness",
        "Randomness and intractability in Kolmogorov complexity",
        "Pseudodeterministic constructions in subexponential time",
        "Pseudo-derandomizing learning and approximation",
        "Searching for primitive roots in finite fields",
        "Pseudorandom generators without the XOR lemma",
        "Simple extractors for all min-entropies and a new pseudorandom generator",
        "Efficient Checking of Polynomials and Proofs anf the Hardness of Approximation Problems",
        "Decoding of Reed Solomon codes beyond the error-correction bound",
        "Deterministic methods to find primes",
        "Pseudorandomness and average-case complexity via uniform reductions",
        "Introduction to coding theory",
        "The geometry of rounding",
        "Theory and applications of trapdoor functions (extended abstract)"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 57 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Polynomial-Time Pseudodeterministic Construction of Primes, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
